heisig_story: Remember when your granny used to ask you to bend your arms at the elbows and hold them out so that she could use them like a rack to hold a skein of string or yarn (here thread) while she rolled it up into a little ball? Now can you see the two elbows (with the second stroke doubling up) at the top, and the character for little below?
koohiiStory1: I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I¬¥ve opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as dainty (#1363) and accumulate (#1364).
koohiiStory2: You¬¥ll be seeing this one a lot. Seriously.
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The thread radical and thread are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: This is why it's good to make sure you know your radicals.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You have some thread... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to eat („ÅÑ„Å®) the thread.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Think about how it tastes. Think about how it feels in your throat. Let it get caught on your teeth and around your tongue. It's a weird feeling having thread in your mouth, and you want to use that weird feeling to remember you're going to eat it.
humanum_full_description_en:
Like a bundle of silk, the upper and lower ends or the thread, the original meaning is filament. In the later generations, all the characters related to " silk " will have "Á≥∏" as the side or main component. In the earlier ancient scripts, "Á≥∏" and " silk " were the same character (Qiu Xigui), which was later split into two characters. In Oracle, "Á≥∏" and "Âπ∫" are indistinguishable from each other. In addition, "Á≥∏" is similar to " beam " and "Ê©ê", which is easy to confuse. See " beam ", "Ê©ê". "Said Wen": "Ship, fine silk. It is shaped like a bundle of silk. All the genus of Shi is from Shi. Read Ruoyu. ¢ÜØ, ancient Wenshi."

The oracle bone inscription is used as the name of the person, 21306B in "Compilation": "Âç£ is more than the blame, death (no) °Ü• (worry)", it is pointed out that Âç£ assists Shi to perform the blame and sacrifice, and there is nothing worth worrying about.

The inscription "Á≥∏" is used as the name of the clan, and the father Renjue: "Father Ren." During the Warring States period, there was also the word "Á≥∏" on the sword coin of Yan Kingdom. Its meaning is unknown.

The original meaning of " shito " refers to filaments is still found in handed down documents, but the original text has been corrupted as " line ". "tube. "Qing Zhong Ding": "You have a weaving status and belong to [Á≥∏]", which means that if you want to tax silk, you must levy taxes on silk. " Shito " also has a small meaning from the filament, "Guangya. Interpretation IV": "Shito, Wei Ye."
humanum_short_description_en: shaped like a bundle of silk, upper and lower ends or threaded, the original meaning is filament. In the later generations, all the characters related to " silk " will have "Á≥∏" as the side or main component.

Like a bundle of silk, the upper and lower ends or the thread, the original meaning is filament. In the later generations, all the characters related to " silk" will have " Á≥∏" as the side or main component. In the earlier ancient scripts, " Á≥∏" and " silk" were the same character (Qiu Xigui), which was later split into two characters. In Oracle, " Á≥∏" and " Âπ∫" are indistinguishable from each other. In addition, " Á≥∏" is similar to " beam" and " Ê©ê", which is easy to confuse. See " beam", " Ê©ê". "Said Wen": "Ship, fine silk. It is shaped like a bundle of silk. All the genus of Shi is from Shi. Read Ruoyu. ¢ÜØ, ancient Wenshi." The oracle bone inscription is used as the name of the person, 21306B in "Compilation": "Âç£ is more than the blame, death (no) °Ü• (worry)", it is pointed out that Âç£ assists Shi to perform the blame and sacrifice, and there is nothing worth worrying about. The inscription " Á≥∏" is used as the name of the clan, and the father Renjue: "Father Ren." During the Warring States period, there was also the word " Á≥∏" on the sword coin of Yan Kingdom. Its meaning is unknown. The original meaning of " shito" refers to filaments is still found in handed down documents, but the original text has been corrupted as " line". "tube. "Qing Zhong Ding": "You have a weaving status and belong to [Á≥∏]", which means that if you want to tax silk, you must levy taxes on silk. " Shito" also has a small meaning from the filament, "Guangya. Interpretation IV": "Shito, Wei Ye."

Radicals: Á≥∏  (thread)
Meaning Mnemonic
The thread radical and thread are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
This is why it's good to make sure you know your radicals.
Reading Mnemonic
You have some thread... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to eat („ÅÑ„Å®) the thread.
Think about how it tastes. Think about how it feels in your throat. Let it get caught on your teeth and around your tongue. It's a weird feeling having thread in your mouth, and you want to use that weird feeling to remember you're going to eat it.
